00085 inline void sc_module_name::clear_module( sc_module* module_p )
00086 {
00087     sc_assert( m_module_p == module_p );
00088     m_module_p = module_p = 0; // avoid unused parameter warning (module_p)
00089 }
00090 
00091 inline void sc_module_name::set_module( sc_module* module_p )
00092 {

00110 // Revision 1.4  2006/03/14 23:56:58  acg
00111 //   Andy Goodrich: This fixes a bug when an exception is thrown in
00112 //   sc_module::sc_module() for a dynamically allocated sc_module
00113 //   object. We are calling sc_module::end_module() on a module that has
00114 //   already been deleted. The scenario runs like this:
00115 //
00116 //   a) the sc_module constructor is entered
00117 //   b) the exception is thrown
00118 //   c) the exception processor deletes the storage for the sc_module
00119 //   d) the stack is unrolled causing the sc_module_name instance to be deleted
00120 //   e) ~sc_module_name() calls end_module() with its pointer to the sc_module
00121 //   f) because the sc_module has been deleted its storage is corrupted,
00122 //      either by linking it to a free space chain, or by reuse of some sort
00123 //   g) the m_simc field is garbage
00124 //   h) the m_object_manager field is also garbage
00125 //   i) an exception occurs
00126 //
00127 //   This does not happen for automatic sc_module instances since the
00128 //   storage for the module is not reclaimed its just part of the stack.
00129 //
00130 //   I am fixing this by having the destructor for sc_module clear the
00131 //   module pointer in its sc_module_name instance. That cuts things at
00132 //   step (e) above, since the pointer will be null if the module has
00133 //   already been deleted. To make sure the module stack is okay, I call
00134 //   end-module() in ~sc_module in the case where there is an
00135 //   sc_module_name pointer lying around.
00136 //
00137 // Revision 1.3  2006/01/13 18:44:30  acg
00138 // Added $Log to record CVS changes into the source.
